Here is the problem statement:

Suppose lim⁡n→∞an=a\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} a_n = an→∞lim​an​=a, lim⁡n→∞bn=b\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} b_n = bn→∞lim​bn​=b, and sn=an3+4anbn2+1s_n = \dfrac{a_n^3+4a_n}{b_n^2+1}sn​=bn2​+1an3​+4an​​. Prove lim⁡n→∞sn=a3+4ab2+a\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \frac{a^3 + 4a}{b^2 + a}n→∞lim​sn​=b2+aa3+4a​ carefully, using the limit theorems.

I emphasized the word "carefully" because it's the reason why I was fairly strict with grading. Many of you had something like this as the first line:

lim⁡n→∞sn=lim⁡n→∞(an3+4an)lim⁡n→∞(bn2+1)(Theorem 9.6)\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \frac{\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{a_n^3 + 4a_n}}{\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{b_n^2 + 1}} \quad \p{\text{Theorem 9.6}}n→∞lim​sn​=limn→∞​(bn2​+1)limn→∞​(an3​+4an​)​(Theorem 9.6)

Theorem 9.6 says the following:

If {sn}n\set{s_n}_n{sn​}n​ converges to sss and {tn}n\set{t_n}_n{tn​}n​ converges to ttt with t≠0t \neq 0t=0, then {tnsn}n\set{\frac{t_n}{s_n}}_n{sn​tn​​}n​ converges to ts\frac{t}{s}st​.

Remember that you need to check assumptions before using a fact. The assumptions for Theorem 9.6 are that lim⁡n→∞sn\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} s_nn→∞lim​sn​ and lim⁡n→∞tn\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} t_nn→∞lim​tn​ exist. In other words, if you wrote the line above before checking that the limits of the numerator and denominator exist, you used Theorem 9.6 before checking all assumptions. So while you get the "correct" answer in the end, the reasoning is wrong, which is why I took off a lot of points.

To prove this properly, Theorem 9.6 turns out to be the last limit law that you use in this problem. A correct solution would look like the following:

By Theorem 9.4,

lim⁡n→∞an3=(lim⁡n→∞an)3=a3andlim⁡n→∞bn2=(lim⁡n→∞bn)2=b2,\lim_{n\to\infty} a_n^3 = \p{\lim_{n\to\infty} a_n}^3 = a^3 \quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{n\to\infty} b_n^2 = \p{\lim_{n\to\infty} b_n}^2 = b^2,n→∞lim​an3​=(n→∞lim​an​)3=a3andn→∞lim​bn2​=(n→∞lim​bn​)2=b2,

and by Theorem 9.2, lim⁡n→∞4an=4a\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} 4a_n = 4an→∞lim​4an​=4a. Thus, by Theorem 9.3,

lim⁡n→∞(an3+4an)=(lim⁡n→∞an3)+(lim⁡n→∞4an)=a3+4a,andlim⁡n→∞(bn2+1)=(lim⁡n→∞bn2)+(lim⁡n→∞1)=b2+1.\begin{aligned} \lim_{n\to\infty} \p{a_n^3 + 4a_n} = \p{\lim_{n\to\infty} a_n^3} + \p{\lim_{n\to\infty} 4a_n} &= a^3 + 4a, \quad\text{and} \\ \lim_{n\to\infty} \p{b_n^2 + 1} = \p{\lim_{n\to\infty} b_n^2} + \p{\lim_{n\to\infty} 1} &= b^2 + 1. \end{aligned}n→∞lim​(an3​+4an​)=(n→∞lim​an3​)+(n→∞lim​4an​)n→∞lim​(bn2​+1)=(n→∞lim​bn2​)+(n→∞lim​1)​=a3+4a,and=b2+1.​

Since b2+1≥1b^2 + 1 \geq 1b2+1≥1, we know that b2+1≠0b^2 + 1 \neq 0b2+1=0, so now we can apply Theorem 9.6 to get

lim⁡n→∞sn=lim⁡n→∞(an3+4an)lim⁡n→∞(bn2+1)=a3+4ab2+1.\lim_{n\to\infty} s_n = \frac{\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{a_n^3 + 4a_n}}{\lim_{n\to\infty} \p{b_n^2 + 1}} = \frac{a^3 + 4a}{b^2 + 1}.n→∞lim​sn​=limn→∞​(bn2​+1)limn→∞​(an3​+4an​)​=b2+1a3+4a​.

Continuity

Introduction

Definition

Suppose f ⁣:D→R\func{f}{D}{\R}f:D→R is a function. Then fff is continuous at x0∈Dx_0 \in Dx0​∈D if one of the following holds:

  1. If {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ is a sequence in DDD converging to x0x_0x0​, then {f(xn)}n\set{f\p{x_n}}_n{f(xn​)}n​ converges to f(x0)f\p{x_0}f(x0​).
  2. For any ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that whenever y∈Dy \in Dy∈D satisfies ∣x0−y∣<δ\abs{x_0 - y} < \delta∣x0​−y∣<δ, then ∣f(x0)−f(y)∣<ε\abs{f\p{x_0} - f\p{y}} < \epsilon∣f(x0​)−f(y)∣<ε.
Remark.

From lecture, you already know that (i) and (ii) are equivalent definitions, which means we can use whichever one's more convenient for us. As a rule of thumb, (i) is easier to use to prove something is discontinuous, and (ii) is easier to use to prove something is continuous.

Another consequence of the sequence definition of continuity is that facts about sequences translate directly into facts about continuity.

Theorem

Suppose f ⁣:D→R\func{f}{D}{\R}f:D→R and g ⁣:D→R\func{g}{D}{\R}g:D→R are continuous functions. Then:

  1. f+gf + gf+g is continuous.
  2. fgfgfg is continuous.
  3. fg\frac{f}{g}gf​ is continuous at all points x0∈Dx_0 \in Dx0​∈D such that g(x0)≠0g\p{x_0} \neq 0g(x0​)=0.
Proof.
(sketch)

Continuity at a point x0∈Dx_0 \in Dx0​∈D basically boils down to sequences. For f+gf + gf+g, if {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ is a sequence in DDD that converges to x0x_0x0​, then we need to show that {(f+g)(xn)}n\set{\p{f + g}\p{x_n}}_n{(f+g)(xn​)}n​ converges to (f+g)(x0)\p{f + g}\p{x_0}(f+g)(x0​), but this boils down to the limit laws for sequences. □\square□

This theorem tells us that sequences help us with proving continuity. The converse is also true: we can use continuity to help us calculate limits.

To end this section, here's an important connection between density and continuity:

Proposition

Let f ⁣:R→R\func{f}{\R}{\R}f:R→R and g ⁣:R→R\func{g}{\R}{\R}g:R→R be continuous functions such that f(q)=g(q)f\p{q} = g\p{q}f(q)=g(q) for all q∈Qq \in \Qq∈Q. Then f=gf = gf=g everywhere.
Remark.

The idea behind this fact is that a continuous function will "fill in gaps" through limits. For example, let's say I give you all the information about a function f(x)f\p{x}f(x) except at a single point:

Because of continuity, there's only one way you can fill in the gap. In other words, information about a continuous function except at one point is the same thing as information about the continuous function everywhere.

The proposition says something a bit stronger: information about a continuous function at the rational numbers is the same as information about the function on the whole real line.
Proof.

To prove the statement, we just need to use density of Q\QQ. Let x0∈Rx_0 \in \Rx0​∈R, so by density of Q\QQ, there exists a sequence of rational numbers {qn}n\set{q_n}_n{qn​}n​ which converge to x0x_0x0​. Since we know that fff and ggg agree at every rational, we have f(qn)=g(qn)f\p{q_n} = g\p{q_n}f(qn​)=g(qn​) for all nnn. Then by the sequence definition of continuity,

f(x0)=lim⁡n→∞f(qn)=lim⁡n→∞g(qn)=g(x0).f\p{x_0} = \lim_{n\to\infty} f\p{q_n} = \lim_{n\to\infty} g\p{q_n} = g\p{x_0}.f(x0​)=n→∞lim​f(qn​)=n→∞lim​g(qn​)=g(x0​).

Since x0x_0x0​ was arbitrary, this means f=gf = gf=g everywhere on R\RR, which was what we wanted to show. □\square□

True or False

Example 4.

True or false: f ⁣:R∖{0}→R\func{f}{\R \setminus \set{0}}{\R}f:R∖{0}→R defined by f(x)=1xf\p{x} = \frac{1}{x}f(x)=x1​ is continuous.
Solution.

True. Continuity of a function only depends on points in the domain. x0=0x_0 = 0x0​=0 is a problematic point for fff, but 000 is outside the domain of fff, so we don't care what happens there.
Example 5.

True or false: If f+gf + gf+g is continuous, then fff or ggg is must be continuous at at least one point.
Solution.

False. For example, let

f(x)={1if x∈Q,0otherwise.f\p{x} = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } x \in \Q, \\ 0 & \text{otherwise}. \end{cases}f(x)={10​if x∈Q,otherwise.​

Then if g=−fg = -fg=−f, we get f+g=0f + g = 0f+g=0 which is continuous everywhere, but fff and ggg are both discontinuous everywhere. This is because Q\QQ and R∖Q\R \setminus \QR∖Q are both dense in R\RR, so given any x0∈Rx_0 \in \Rx0​∈R, there exist a sequence {qn}n\set{q_n}_n{qn​}n​ of rational numbers and a sequence {rn}n\set{r_n}_n{rn​}n​ of irrational numbers which both converge to x0x_0x0​. But

f(qn)=1andf(rn)=0for all n∈N,f\p{q_n} = 1 \quad\text{and}\quad f\p{r_n} = 0 \quad\text{for all } n \in \N,f(qn​)=1andf(rn​)=0for all n∈N,

so by the sequence definition of continuity, fff is discontinuous everywhere.
Example 6.

True or false: If f+gf + gf+g is continuous and fff is continuous, then ggg is continuous.
Solution.

True. You can write

g=(f+g)⏟continuous+(−f)⏟continuous,g = \underbrace{\p{f + g}}_{\text{continuous}} + \underbrace{\p{-f}}_{\text{continuous}},g=continuous(f+g)​​+continuous(−f)​​,

so ggg is a sum of continuous functions, hence continuous.
